Document Number: 4.2.1 
 
Revision Date: 2024/Jan/02 
OSP Product Standardization – Fibre & Connectivity 
Confidential 
 
Page 2 of 26 
OSP Product Standardization – Fibre & 
Connectivity 
 
Objective: 
Objective: To Evaluate and standardize Xplore Outside Plant (OSP) Fibre network equipment. Establish 
Xplore Fibre OSP preferences and requirement. Determine “Standard” and “Acceptable Alternate” choice 
in each category for Xplore Fibre deployment across the nation.  
Not within the scope: Individual product performance evaluation as these products are already trialed, 
tested, and widely deployed by other service providers in Canada and other parts of the world. Instead 
focused on how individual products integrate and perform to Xplore fibre network and overall operations 
and maintenance 
 
 
Relationship to existing Xplore Wireline National Standards: 
1. NONE 
 
 
 
 




![Xplore logo featuring the name "Xplore" and a stylized "X" in a modern design.

Xplore® X](#)

XNS Xplore National Standards – Fibre 
  
Document Number: 4.2.1 
 
Revision Date: 2024/Jan/02 
OSP Product Standardization – Fibre & Connectivity 
Confidential 
 
Page 5 of 26 
1. Evaluation Metrics 
Evaluation will focus on connectivity, adaptability, easiness of installation, maintenance, and field 
application to other OSP components of Xplore fibre network as a whole system. Individual performance 
will also be considered but preference will be given to components that integrates best to the overall 
network. 
Individual product will be evaluated based on following metrics:  
1. Technical Speciation  
 
– Packaging, Environment, Performance Standards 
2. Systems Engineering   
– How the product interacts with other components 
3. Craftsmanship   
 
– Field installation, deployment, and maintenance  
4. Pricing   
 
 
– Cost per unit 
5. Lead Time and Distribution 
– Time to order and deliver material to warehouse/site 
6. Customer Care   
 
– Post-sale customer/client support service  
2. Evaluation Ratings 
A letter grade rating will be assigned to each metrics listed in Section 1. A breakdown of rating is listed as 
follow: 
Letter Grade Rating 
Description 
A – Excellent  
- 
No issue to report 
- 
Exceed expectation 
- 
No further test is required  
B – Very Good 
 
- 
1 – 2 issues to report 
- 
No further test is required 
C – Good 
 
- 
2 – 4 issues to report  
- 
Field trial is highly recommended  
D – Fair 
 
- 
Major issue(s) to report 
- 
Further study and review is required 
- 
Field trial is mandatory before deployment  
 
Note: The rating is assigned to each metric centric to field application on Xplore fibre network. Issues 
reported do not necessary reflect issue with the product itself but instead associates with field application 
during Xplore fibre network build and operation.  
3. OSP Product Evaluation and Rating 
Only Evaluation Metric 1-3 are rated in this document as 4-6 are beyond the scope of the evaluation at 
this moment. Rating for metric 4-6 will be assigned once more information is given in future date.  
An overall rating will be assigned at the end of each product section which indicates if the product is the 
preferred product of its category – Standard Choice, or “Number 2” choice as acceptable direct 
replacement – Acceptable Alternate Choice, or simply avoid using the product – Not Standard Choice.  
NOTE: Skip to Section 4 for OSP Product Standardization Summary 




![Xplore logo featuring a stylized "X" component with the word "Xplore" in a modern font.

Xplore® X](#)



|Letter Grade Rating|Description|
|---|---|
|A – Excellent|&#45; No issue to report &#45; Exceed expectation &#45; No further test is required|
|B – Very Good|&#45; 1 – 2 issues to report &#45; No further test is required|
|C – Good|&#45; 2 – 4 issues to report &#45; Field trial is highly recommended|
|D – Fair|&#45; Major issue(s) to report &#45; Further study and review is required &#45; Field trial is mandatory before deployment|

 Multi-Port Terminal (MPT) 
3.1.1. Corning Evolv ™ Terminal with Pushlok™ Technology 
Overview:  
Pushlok ™ hardened connector technology is the key component enabling smaller terminals. The terminal 
is up to four times smaller than existing solution allowing users to place on strand, façade and avoid pole-
attachment fees, reduce size of handle and pedestal footprint, and reuse existing infrastructure  
 
Figure 1: Corning Evolv Terminal 
 
Figure 2: Coning Evolv Terminal with Pushlok connector 
 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark 
Technical Specifications 
A 
Compact design 
System Engineering 
A 
Easy to connect with Pushlok plug 
Craftsmanship 
A 
Ease of use, user-friendly, and “dummy’ proof 
 
Pros:  
- 
Compact in size so it fits into smaller supporting infrastructures 
- 
Drop + connector is smaller compare to existing solution 
- 
Easy to install both the terminal and drop connection  
- 
Built-in Splitter is an optional add-on to provide addition option for MxU application other than single 
drop to premise usage

Overall Rating:  
Number 1 Choice: Standard Choice  
 
3.1.2. Corning Optisheath® MultiPort Terminal 
Overview:  
The stubbed/stubless OptiSheath® MultiPort Flex Terminal is designed for use in outside plant fiber 
access networks. In particular, its reliability makes it ideal for FTTH applications. This terminal provides 
sealed environmental protection, as well as easy incremental connection of subscriber drop cables. This 
MultiPort Flex Terminal also accelerates FTTH community acceptance through its ability to fit inside some 
of the most compact pedestals and handholes on the market. It is available in several configurations with 
4, 6, 8, and 12 OptiTap® single-fiber connector ports. 
 
Figure 3: Corning OptiSheath MPT 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark 
Technical Specifications 
A 
Industry leading MPT model 
System Engineering 
B 
Larger footprint with/out bracket 
Craftsmanship 
A 
Easy to install drop (Corning Optitap connector) 
Pros:  
- 
Widely deployed by the industry – durable, easy to maintain (add/remove service) 
- 
Pre-connectorized OptiTap ® drops to customer premises  
Cons:  
- 
Much larger dimension than Corning Evolv Terminal. Pre-connectorized drop has longer lead/tail 
than Corning Evolv Pushlok drop that requires larger footprint for underground application  
Overall Rating:  
Number 2 Choice : Acceptable Alternate Choice

3.1.3. Commscope NOVUX™ Hardened Terminal (HST) 
Overview:  
Successor of Commscope MST which was previously approved. HST is lighter and smaller than MST. 
Similar product to Corning Optisheath MPT in size, connection type, and footprint. It utilizes the same 
OptiTap connector to drop connection.  
Commscope HST and Corning Optisheath Evolv can be use interchangeably depends on the Pricing, 
Lead time and Distribution.  
 
Figure 4: Commscope HST MPT 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark 
Technical Specifications 
A 
Industry leading MPT model 
System Engineering 
A 
Larger footprint with/out bracket 
Craftsmanship 
A 
Easy to install drop (Corning Optitap connector) 
Pros:  
- 
Widely deployed by the industry – durable, easy to maintain (add/remove service) 
- 
Pre-connectorized OptiTap ® drops to customer premises  
Cons:  
- 
Much larger dimension than Corning Evolv Terminal. Pre-connectorized drop has longer lead/tail 
than Corning Evolv Pushlok drop that requires larger footprint for underground application  
Overall Rating:  
Number 2 Choice: Acceptable Alternate Choice 
 
 Drop Cables 
Xplore Fibre Network would prefer drop cable with connectorized on multiport terminal (MPT) end only. The 
field end is mechanically connected, to be spliced to mechanical connector in the field. The reason to avoid 
pre-connectorized drop cable (field end) is to have the flexibility to have custom drop length tailored for 
each application without the need of storing slacks on MPT end or on customer’s demarcation point.  
Round drop cables are preferred for underground application for the easiness to pull cable in and out of 
underground infrastructure which usually has less room to work with the bend radius. Flat drop cables are 
preferred for aerial application due to fitness to wedge clamp on pole. For the application where there is

3.2.1. Corning Evolv ROC™ Drop Cable 
Overview:  
Corning designs and manufactures the ROC™ drop cable assembly with factory-terminated, 
environmentally sealed and hardened connectors to reduce the cost and time of drop cable deployment. 
Corning hardened connectors provide superior durability and reliability in the drop segment of the 
network. This assembly also offers significant improvements in cable management. 
 
Figure 5: Corning Evolv ROC drop with Pushlok 
connector 
 
Figure 6: OptiTap adapter (Left), Pushlok connector 
(Right)

- 
Available with one or both ends connectorized 
- 
Hybrid (one end with an OptiTap Connector, one end with standard SC connector) available with 
or without pulling grip 
Cons:  
- 
Corning only provides flat drop during product evaluation. Fibre bending during installation could 
be an issue compare to typical round drop cable. A special wedge clamp can be purchased for 
aerial pole application to customer premises

3.2.2. Corning / Commscope OptiTap® Drop Cable 
Overview:  
Fiber Optic Drop Cable Assembly for outside plant applications:  
- 
Backward-compatible with older generations of hardened and non-hardened connector systems, 
FHD drop cable integrates seamlessly into existing fiber-optic networks 
- 
Hardened drop cables incorporate hardened connector technology that is designed to withstand 
the rugged outside plant environment 
- 
Hardened drop cables simplify installation and maintenance by reducing splicing requirements in 
the distribution portion of the network

Figure 10: FHD Drop Cable connector

Overall Rating:  
Number 2: Acceptable Alternate choice of drop cable 
 
 Mechanical Connectors for Drop Cable (SC) 
Fibre optic mechanical connector (type SC) is used to connect fibre drop to fibre termination point 
equipment. SC, abbreviated for Subscriber Connector, has also been referred to as Square Connector or 
Standard Connector. It’s a popular fiber-optic connector due to its low-cost, durability and simple 
installation for both point-to-point and passive optical networking. 
SC is a push-pull device that uses a ceramic ferrule to deliver highly accurate alignment in a fiber-optic 
link. It’s a square-shaped connector—also known as “stick and click” for its SC acronym—that comes with 
a locking tab that enables the push-on and pull-off operation 
3.3.1. Corning NPC+ 
Overview:  
The NPC+ (No Polish Connector) eliminates field polishing, loose parts, and termination tools. The 
innovative buffer clamp design eliminates rework by delivering superior twist and transmission with 
applied load (TWAL) mechanical performance. After fiber preparation and cleaving, installation is a simple 
three-step process: insert fiber, actuate splice, activate the buffer clamp. Faster than fusion splicing, the 
NPC+ delivers savings in installation expense and reduces overall complexity of termination 
 
Figure 12: Corning NPC+ SC Connector 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark 
Technical Specifications 
A 
 
System Engineering 
A 
Flexible – OptiTap connector available 
Craftsmanship 
A 
 
Pros:  
- 
Corning mechanical connector has longer channel that fits into connection tightly  
Cons:  
- 
None 
Overall Rating:  
Number 1: Standard choice

3.3.3. AFL FASTConnect SC 
Overview:  
FASTConnect® field-installable connectors are factory pre-polished connectors that completely eliminate 
the need for hand polishing in the field. Proven mechanical splice technology ensuring precision fiber 
alignment, a factory pre-cleaved fiber stub and a proprietary index-matching gel combine to offer an 
immediate low loss termination to either single-mode or multimode optical fibers. 
FASTConnect® connectors are compatible with 250 µm and 900 µm optical fibers, as well as 900 µm, 2 
mm and 3 mm cordage. All primary fiber types are supported, and each connector is color coded per 
industry-standard requirements to aide in identification during and after installation. A factory-installed 
wedge clip (included with each connector) is removed and discarded upon completion of the termination. 
Incorporated into this device is an innovative, translucent wedge enabling the use of a common VFI to 
provide a “pass/fail” signal once physical contact is achieved.

Note: Commscope and AFL mechanical connect looks exactly the same (form factor, size, mould). It will 
come down to price and lead time to choose between these two connectors. Corning connector has more 
secure fit into connector during product evaluation and it does not rock side to side as compare to 
Commscope or AFL connector.  
 
 Fibre Optic Splice Closure (FOSC)  
Xplore Fibre Network would prefer FOSC size that takes up as little footprint as possible. The standard 
FOSC should hold a maximum of 288F fibre cable and the size should be similar, or smaller, to 
Commscope 450C model unless specify by the designer 
 
3.4.1. Commscope FOSC-450’s 
Overview:  
The FOSC-450 is a single-ended, environmentally sealed enclosure for fiber management in the outside 
plant network. FOSC-450 gel splice closures have the same splice capacity as FOSC-400 closures and 
feature the same reliable and easy-to-use dome-to-base clamping system. The major difference between 
the closures is that the FOSC-450’s cable sealing terminations use gel-sealing technology instead of heat 
shrink. The FOSC-450 features a single wrap-around gel seal with four or six cable ports. The single seal 
slides easily into the closure’s base for rapid, secure installation. Gel-seal cable terminations automatically 
adjust to cable size and shape, and require no special tools or accessories to install. It is easy to remove 
cables, and gel seal is completely re-usable.

3.4.2. Corning Fibre Dome Closure with ECAM Port 
Overview:  
The fiber dome closure family has earned its reputation for reliable protection of fiber optic facilities – 
delivering a full line of closures and accessories. Now, it also includes new models and configurations for 
more flexibility to meet the complex needs of today’s fiber optic networks.  
Fibre Dome Closures utilizes the external cable assembly module (ECAM) built-in cable entry port 
system, which allows true plug-and-play capability. This reduces installation and labor costs because the 
cable preparation and installation are completed outside of the closure body — allowing the tech to add/ 
remove cables from the closure without breaking the cable seals of previously installed cables.  
Corning Fibre Dome Closure intended to meet the needs of anyone using fiber optic splice closures in the 
long haul, metro, local access (xDSL, HFC, wireless backhaul), and FTTx feeder/distribution networks. It 
is designed for butt, single, or ribbon fiber applications. It is tested to Telcordia’s GR-771-CORE Generic 
Requirements for fiber optic splice closures. It requires no special tools, which reduces tooling costs and 
allows for ease of installation and re-entry into the closure.

3.4.3. Channell – Green Hornet Series 
Overview:  
The Green Hornet Series is a high-performance, sealed, butt splice closure capable of performing in the 
harshest environments. The FOSC excels in underground/vault, pedestal, and aerial applications to deliver 
high-speed fiber communication in any outside plant application. It can be used in straight or branch 
applications with a capacity of up to 144F splices. Green Hornet is ideal in FTTH applications where up to 
twelve (12) drops can be deployed. The oval main cable seal enables mid-sheath cable splices where uncut 
fibers are stored and expressed through the closure. Green Hornet can be deployed with an integrated 16-
port adapter bulkhead in SC or LC footprints. Channell’s grommet technology provides easy cable 
installation, robust sealing, and cable strain relief retention. The grommets are designed to seal all types of 
incoming and drop cables in various diameters, constructions, and sizes. The splice closure may be ordered 
packaged with a pedestal or grade level vault delivering the best overall value in a complete package.  
FEATURES:  
- 
Environmentally Sealed: Air Water Tight  
- 
Craft-Friendly Design  
- 
Quick and Tool-less Installation  
- 
Re-enterable and Re-useable  
TESTING SPECIFICATIONS:  
- 
Meets GR771, IP68, and IEC 61300 test standards 
 
Figure 18: Channell Green Hornet Enclsore (G5N is shown)

3.4.4. PLP – Coyote® Dome Closure 
Overview:  
The COYOTE® Dome Closures have the versatility and features that make it a perfect choice for fiber-to-
the premises networks. Both the 6.5" and 9.5" dome closure designs use PLP’s patented segmented end 
plate system which allows independent access to each cable port without disruption to surrounding 
cables.

 Inline Terminal 
3.5.1. Corning OptiSheath SCA-9T Aerial Inline Terminal 
Overview 
The Corning OptiSheath SCA-9T Aerial Inline Terminal, available in 24" and 34" (taut sheath) versions, 
provides environmental protection and quick incremental connection of customer OptiTap drop cable with 
provisions for cable strain-relief, sealing of all cables and quick-release clamps for easy terminal re-entry. 
This aerial application is a cost effective method used as an alternative to long tail MPT builds.  This 
method works well in the rural application where long tail MPT design does not make sense. These 
terminals act as a splice case and terminal all in one unit. Feeder and distribution counts can be placed in 
the same fibre cable sheath with additional options to add extra ports if ever required. 
Although there are 8 & 12 port options available, try avoid using them and stay to 6 port or less option if 
all possible. he reason being is that you can only fit 6 ports per end with the ports facing the pole, so I&R 
can easily plug in the fibre drop. If the ports are placed on the far end, it is 24” further away and won’t be 
reachable from the pole. This could cause non-doable work or require bucket truck requirements when 
placing the fibre drop. 
 
Figure 20: Corning OptiSheath SCA-9T Aerial Inline Terminal (24") 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark 
Technical Specifications 
A 
 
System Engineering 
A 
 
 
Craftsmanship 
A 
 
 
 
Pros:  
- 
Ideal for mid-span splice. 6 port MPT knock out on each end and up to 12 ports in total 
- 
Fits up to 144F fibre, ideal for Xplore fibre network deployment 
Cons:  
- 
None 
Overall Rating:  
Number 1: Standard choice

3.5.2. Corning OptiSheath SCA-9T Aerial Inline Terminal 
Overview 
Channell’s Yellow Jacket Aerial Terminal is a robust, multiport solution for above ground fiber optic 
deployments. The Yellow Jacket provides extreme environmental protection in the harshest conditions 
and facilitates quick connection of up to 16 drop cables each with individual strain relief.  
Gaining entry to the Yellow Jacket terminal is quick and easy through its cover compression clamps. The 
terminal is designed to mount effortlessly on a strand (aerial mounting brackets included) and is capable 
of accommodating 4 distribution cable entry ports in either direction for maximum flexibility. 
The Yellow Jacket allows for ample slack storage and is compatible with Channell’s Universal Splice 
Trays for a maximum splice capacity up to 144F. Multiple splitter configurations can be accommodated for 
both centralized and distributed split deployments.  
 
Figure 21: Channell Yellow Jacket Aerial Inline Terminal 
 
Metric 
Rating 
Remark

The design and build of this terminal does not fit Xplore fibre network deployment. It is not ideal for direct 
substitute of Corning OptiSheath product.  
Overall Rating:  
Not Standard Choice of Inline Terminal

Wirewerks’ NextSTEP™ 1U Rack Mount Patch Panel features an industry-first horizontal slot design for 
mounting slide-in NextSTEP Fiber Modules and cassettes. Each horizontal slot is ‘stepped’ (offset) from

adjacent slots, providing easy physical and visual access to any individual fiber module without disrupting 
other modules or fibers co-resident in the same panel. 
NextSTEP 1U Patch Panels feature unrestricted front and rear access for easy installation and 
maintenance. The guide-rail system that secures each slide-in/out module into place features ‘click in-
place’ stops that indicate when a module is properly seated in its correct operational position as well as 
partially withdrawn positions for easy technician access. 
NextSTEP 1U Patch Panels are compatible with all NextSTEP Fiber Modules, and accept up to twelve 
(12) single-slot modules in any combination in any slot position. NextSTEP Modules slide in or out from 
the front or rear of the panel without tools -- making installations, MACs, and maintenance fast, easy and 
cost-effective. 
Fiber counts in 1RU for typical configurations include up to 144F with LC/SC-Patch or Distribution 
Modules; up to 288F with Splice Tray Modules; and up to 1,152F with MPO Adapter Strip Modules.

centralized split points in a PON network. The 72, 96, 144, and 288 ﬁber termination choices allow 
operators to scale the cabinet cost to their network design.

3.8.2. Corning LS Series FDH (288F) 
Overview 
The OptiTect® Local Convergence Cabinet, LS Series provides everything necessary to manage up to 
288 fibers for an outside plant FTTx application. The OptiTect Local Convergence Cabinet, LS Series is 
an innovative solution that is the optimal balance between size, density and access. All cabinets share 
the same intuitive and efficient cable routing and splitter storage. The LS cabinet was developed with the 
field craft in mind. In this unique cabinet design, splitter parking and cable toning are simple, providing 
customers more flexibility and deployment options. The best-in-class fiber routing design allows for quick 
subscriber turn-up and error-free long-term maintenance as the cabinet is loaded to capacity. Cabinet 
offer “pass-through” capabilities for commercial services or other high-bandwidth applications, as well as 
multiple mounting options to accommodate exclusive below ground and aerial plant installations. 
 
Figure 24: Corning FDH LS Series

Technical Specifications

A 
 
 
Summary: 
The Corning FDH is heavy so it is not ideal of Pole-Mounted application. It has good seal at the door and 
the cabinet is sturdy built. Every connection is terminated in the front so technician does not need to go to 
the back for any patching.

3.8.3. Commscope Outdoor FDH 3000 
Overview 
The FDH 3000 is designed to meet and serve the distinct needs of diverse markets and customer 
segments. The unique design of the FDH 3000 provides for rapid connection between fiber optic cables 
and passive optical splitters in the outside plant segment of the network, facilitating fast service 
connection and reconfiguration, simplified network installations and improved installation efficiencies in 
the field

cabinet shelf. Not as user-friendly as other models compared.

Page 24 of 26 
 Outside Plant Fibre Optic Cable  
Xplore are open to purchase cables from a number of fibre optic cable manufacturers. The standard cables 
to be used as a first choice for the majority of Xplore fibre network application are  
- 
Dielectric & single-jacket fibre optic cable 
- 
Dielectric & double-jacket/double-armour for gopher / rodent infested area as the outer shield is 
sacrificial to the gnawing of the gopher 
- 
All dielectric cables or Poly / Single Jacket used in areas which prevent the use of a cable with a 
metallic shield such as areas of Power Influence 
Advantage of going with dielectric cable is due to lighter weight so it is easier to withstand wind storm 
impact in Maritime provinces. Single Jacket cable without metallic armor does not require permit and 
meet hydro regulation in some territory / municipality. (No Pole-Line-Analysis “PLA” is required in 
Maritime provinces at the time of writing)   
The specification would be Xplore fibre network standards and guidelines unless the type of cable is 
dictated by the utility or regulatory requirement.  
Manufacturers  
- 
Corning SMF-28e+  
- 
AFL – LE Series / LN Series (Rodent Resistant) 
- 
Commscope – D-LN Series  
 
Overall Rating:  
Corning cable would be the standard choice of outdoor fibre optic cable, especially for critical run/path. The 
other manufacturers produce quality fibre optic cables that are also widely deployed across Canada. The 
preference would go to evaluation metrics 4-6 (pricing, lead time and distribution).
